Posts.Title: Help me out here..... KentuckyMom DIL

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 09:56AM kajsa wrote: I try to think that it means a lot to them to help me. They're feeling that they DOING something in a situation where the feel that there's actually nothing much to do. As being the one with the disease you DO things all the time, fighting cancer. You do treatments and try to stay alive, but the close ones around you probably need to feel they're doing something as well, somethings that really help you. That's how I try to look at it, sometimes it works. :)
Posts.Title: How to Stay Independent jleigh steelrose

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2011 02:07AM kajsa wrote: We started to plan yesterday, me and my DH :). We want to go visit the woman I used to be best friend with when we were kids, haven't seen her in 30 years! She lives in NY now, and I would love to see the city as well! Then we're going to LA to visit my cousin who lives there. My DH wants to drive along the coast to SF and it seems like a good idea! Beautiful trip! So, when you all (almost) are coming to Europe I travel to the states :).
Posts.Title: Anyone have a real or imaginary vacation planned in the future? cookie97 NewReality

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2010 12:38PM kajsa wrote: I'm going to take the test next week. Especially my sister and my 21 yo daughter really wants to know and if I were them, I would also I think. My mother died from BC and yes, I think it would have been better if I had known about my genes (if they find anything...) than having BC myself... but that was 20 years ago so there were no test back then. I have two girls (21 and 4 years old) and my sister has two as well (9 and 5 years old) so yes, I can't really see the alternative that not having the test taken. I guess it all works a little bit different in Sweden though, as it doesn't cost anything to do the test (all healthcare costs are payed by taxes).
Posts.Title: Genetic testing? YamaMama YamaMama

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2011 09:56AM kajsa wrote: I was diagnosed with brain mets 5 months ago, had WBR and a week later I was on chemo again. The Navelbine I got wasn't working very well and I got the chance to be in a clinical trial so 2 months later i switched to Xeloda (and Tykerb) and just finished the 3rd round, starting fourth tomorrow...  When I had my DX I just thought I would be dead in weeks, but now I'm feeling quite alright, stronger for everyday, beginning to do normal things again :).  Hugs Kajsa
